item.title: About
item.description:
It took 3 years for me to get to this point.

I first started writing on Medium, left it to drift into one of my ideas-never-fully-realised black holes. I then took to Goodreads, initiated a very ambitious 18-book challenge, but ended up with zero entries. On some days, I found it hard to sleep because my mind was running through ideas I had from the day, and how I would flesh them out in writing. But nothing. Why?

I was (and am) a perfectionist. I wanted to achieve my ideal - the Atlantics, the Brain Pickings - in one single step. Nothing I wrote ever felt good enough, looked the part, or sounded like the ideals I wanted.

Finding one’s voice can be a long journey. Putting one’s thoughts out there on the interwebs does take quite a bit of courage. But you can’t get any better until you put pen to paper, and take that first step.

Inspired by the approach of design thinking to Think, Make, Break, Repeat - here’s my first baby step. A collection of short essays / responses to books I’ve read, interesting news of the day, and my personal projects.

Happy to stay in touch on LinkedIn or GitHub.

item.title: Peeling away the curtain on poverty in Singapore
item.description:
If you’re Singaporean - read this book. If you live in a world where there are people who could own up to twelve cars (cue Selling Sunset), and also people who might not have a roof over their heads - read this book. You will be surprised, challenged, compelled to think, and will keep thinking.

This is Part 1 of my quest to read more Singaporean literature (fiction and non-fiction alike). After hearing so much about Teo You Yenn’s much raved about book “This Is What Inequality Looks Like” - I had to add it to the list. The verdict - a very solid five stars.

But be prepared: reading TIWILL is uncomfortable. It offers not only a level of scrutiny over the lives of a group of people often considered “invisible”, but also a deep examination into the values and preconceptions of the reader. The book achieves the same effect that I believe Parasite did for many viewers - introducing an undercurrent of thinking, generating more thoughts with yet another observation of something (an object, a person, an activity). Previously innocuous, but now laden with meaning.

TIWILL is very much a collection of vignettes - providing a peek into multiple dimensions of the lives of the low-income. Teo has (quite consciously, I believe) avoided dramatising these differences - instead, she invites you to step into the smallness, but also the warmth, of the homes of a socio-economic group that is often swept under the carpet. As the reader is immersed in the physical, mental, and emotional spaces in which the low-income operate in daily, he/she is inadvertently forced to challenge his/her understanding (and/or stereotypes) around what poverty looks like, what drives poverty, and why poverty is so difficult to change / eradicate.

TIWILL doesn’t offer answers to how the situation for lower-income individuals can be improved - it is, after all, highly complex (something which readers will better appreciate by the end of the book) and this book is not written with the purpose of directing / defining policy. But TIWILL provides exactly the first step we need: to start thinking about who we are, who we want to be, what we want our society to be.

As Teo writes:

“We who have the power to make choices disproportionately shape outcomes and limit options for those people who don’t have the power to make choices.”

If you are on Goodreads, the same review can be found here.

item.title: Surgery on the brain of a neurosurgeon
item.description:
I try not to give away too much on my book reviews (especially since they go onto Goodreads and qualifying everything with spoilers is a chore). But I especially loved this very personal journey into the mind of one of Britain’s greatest neurosurgeons - his triumphs, his failures, and the emotional turmoil behind the scenes.

This was a very refreshing genre for me - I’ve had my fair share of medical TV dramas but not dived into books like these. Another major draw is the context in which this book is situated - the field of neurosurgery, which is still very much a fascinating black box.

Henry Marsh writes wonderfully: he has a strong and distinctive voice that tells you as it is - not only about his experiences, but also who he is as a person, unabashedly. (Whether you think you might like the man as a friend or colleague is a separate matter altogether.)

Through this very real and personal account, Marsh achieves the objective he established at the beginning of the book - reminding us as readers that doctors are not as superhuman as we make them to be, and they too go through very human challenges.

P.S. A very timely read as our medical workers on the frontlines are working tirelessly and doing their best to keep us all safe in COVID-19 times. Show your appreciation where you can!
